content.name: Pear Technologies
content.culture: Tech cult obsessed with dimensional mapping
content.want: Data. The deeper the better. In Pear-proprietary formats, naturally.
content.pay: Good base, excellent bonuses for deep survey data.
content.vibe: Sleek. Smug. Their equipment only works with other Pear equipment.

contracts.name: Deep Survey
contracts.desc: Enter a rift and map it. Plant Pear sensor arrays. Collect environmental data.

contracts.name: Tech Recovery
contracts.desc: Previous survey team went dark. Recover their equipment (and data).

contracts.name: Anomaly Documentation
contracts.desc: Something weird happened in a rift. Document it. Don't touch it.

content.text: Doctrine: Survey (primary), Acquisition (secondary) Culture Origin: Ancient consumer technology company. Sleek devices. Proprietary ecosystems. Planned obsolescence. A founder who wore simple clothes and spoke in revelations. A thousand years later, the founder is a genuine saint ‚Äî the Visionary, depicted in iconography as a robed figure holding a single luminous fruit. The product launches are holy days. The devices are sacraments. And the ecosystem is now a literal closed society where every piece of technology, every augment, every interface in your body must be Pear-compatible or it doesn‚Äôt work.

Aesthetic: White and silver. Minimalist. Clean. Every surface is a screen. Every screen is an interface. Every interface connects to the Network, which is Pear‚Äôs proprietary information architecture ‚Äî a system so deeply integrated into daily life that citizens experience withdrawal symptoms when disconnected. The architecture is beautiful. The stores are temples. The Genius Bars are confessionals where technician-priests diagnose your spiritual and technical ailments.

Citizen Identity: Users. Not pejoratively ‚Äî reverently. To Use is to participate in the Network. To be Connected is to be alive. Disconnection is exile. Obsolescence is death. Citizens upgrade constantly ‚Äî not just devices but themselves. Augments must be Pear-certified. Non-certified modifications void your warranty, which in Pear territory means voiding your citizenship. The most Connected citizen ‚Äî the one running the most current version of themselves ‚Äî has the highest status.

What They Want From Rifts: Data. Dimensional topology. Information architecture from other realities. Pear‚Äôs Survey doctrine is about mapping everything ‚Äî not just rift geography but the underlying information structure of other dimensions. They believe (and they might be right) that reality itself is an operating system, and the rifts are access points to the source code. If they can read it, they can write it. Every other corp thinks Pear is being dramatic. Pear thinks every other corp lacks vision.

Pay: Data-weighted. Base pay is average. Bonuses for quality data are enormous. A survey that produces a new predictive model for rift behavior is worth a small fortune. A survey that returns corrupted data pays minimum. Pear‚Äôs payment system is, naturally, proprietary and requires a Pear-compatible financial interface to access.

Working For Pear: Sleek. Condescending. Pear treats contractors the way a temple treats visiting barbarians ‚Äî with polite tolerance and the unshakeable belief that you‚Äôd be happier if you just converted. Briefings are delivered via holographic presentation with soundtrack. Equipment is excellent and only compatible with other Pear equipment. The technician-priests who handle your debriefing are genuinely brilliant and genuinely confused by anyone who uses non-Pear augments. ‚ÄúWhy would you do that to yourself?‚Äú they ask, with the sincere concern of missionaries encountering the unbaptized.
